facts.text: The appellant was tried for murder under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code in the court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Alipore sitting with a jury.
The jury returned a verdict of not guilty and the appellant was acquitted.
Against that order the State took an appeal to the High Court (Government Appeal No. 14 of 1956).

The Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court found that there was mis-direction in the charge to the jury and therefore after consideration of the evidence it set aside the verdict of the jury, allowed the appeal and sentenced the appellant to imprisonment for life. Judgment dated September 18, 1959.
The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) which was granted by another Division Bench of the Court which had not heard the appeal.

Three points urged before the Bench for certificate: 1. unusual delay in delivering the judgment and the Division Bench hearing the appeal forgot to consider many of the questions of fact raised; 2. High Court had no power to substitute its own estimate of the evidence in an appeal against acquittal in trial by jury; 3. no such misdirection as caused failure of justice or mistrial, so High Court not entitled to examine evidence.

Certificate granted on ground of unusual delay in delivering judgment, which may have led to some points in paragraph 18 of the petition being lost sight of; these points were argued by defence counsel.
Points in paragraph 18 were questions of fact.

legal_issues.text: Whether the certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) is a proper certificate and should therefore be cancelled.
Whether it is a case in which special leave to appeal should be granted under Art. 136.

petitioner_arguments.text: There was unusual delay in delivering the judgment and the Division Bench forgot to consider many questions of fact raised.
High Court had no power to substitute its own estimate of the evidence in an appeal against acquittal in trial by jury.
No such misdirection as caused failure of justice or mistrial, so High Court not entitled to examine evidence.
Special leave should be granted under Art. 136 as record printed and appeal could be properly argued.

respondent_arguments.text: Points raised were questions of fact; High Court has no jurisdiction to grant certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) on mere question of fact.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Haripada Dey v. State of West Bengal; Sidheswar Ganguly v. State of West Bengal

respondent_arguments.text: Delay in judgment and possible overlooking of factual points not ground for certificate.

court_reasoning.text: High Court granted certificate on mere ground of delay in delivering judgment and possible loss sight of factual points argued; such points are questions of fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court has no jurisdiction to grant certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) on mere question of fact.

court_reasoning.text: Certifying is a strong word; High Court not justified in granting certificate on mere facts or converting Supreme Court into court of appeal on facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Precedents in Haripada Dey and Sidheswar Ganguly hold no certificate on facts or summary dismissal grounds.

court_reasoning.text: Mere delay does not make case fit for appeal; analogy to s.109(c) CPC requires great public importance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Certificate improper and must be cancelled.

court_reasoning.text: No reason to grant special leave under Art. 136.

holdings.text: The certificate granted by the Calcutta High Court was not a proper certificate and must be cancelled.
No special leave to appeal under Art. 136.

precedents_cited.case_name: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court has no jurisdiction to grant certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) on mere question of fact.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sidheswar Ganguly v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: No certificate on ground of summary dismissal or mere facts; must involve complexities of law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Banarsi Parshad v. Kashi Krishna Narain
precedents_cited.relevance: Under s.109(c) CPC, certificate requires case of great public importance.
Under s.109(c) CPC, certificate requires case of great public importance.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence for which appellant was tried.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate and special leave provisions; grounds for fitness for appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogy for interpreting certificate requirement as needing great public importance.

outcome.summary: Preliminary objection upheld; certificate under Art.134(1)(c) cancelled as improperly granted on ground of delay and factual oversights. No special leave under Art.136 granted.

key_quotes.text: "Certifying is a strong word and therefore, it has been repeatedly pointed out that a High Court is in error in granting a certificate on a mere question of fact."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains strict standard for Art.134(1)(c) certificates.

key_quotes.text: "A mere ground of delay in giving a judgment does not, in our opinion, fall within the words 'fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court'."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly rejects basis for the certificate granted.
